Award.AwardTitle: Computational Modeling and Design of Cytochrome P450 Reactivity and Substrate Specificity

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0967062
Maranas

Enzymes are versatile structures tuned by nature to selectively carry on a vast array of catalytic functions. Their potential to provide solutions to challenges in biomass treatment, biofuels production, biosensing, wastewater and environmental pollutants treatment has long been recognized. However, many of these enzymes suffer from poor stability under the desired reaction conditions, or have inadequate catalytic activity, or a lack of specificity for non-native substrate molecules. The rational design of enzymes for improved or novel catalytic activity remains an open challenge because catalytic efficiency depends on the nature of the molecules to be reacted, and reflects a balance of active site access and binding with improved transition state stabilization. High throughput experimentation will not work here due to the difficulty and cost of screening and the enormity of the combinatorial design space.

The trio of PIs, Costas Maranas, Patrick Cirino and Michael Janik, all at Pennsylvania State University, seek to address these shortcomings in a systematic fashion, by first developing a multi-scale computational work-flow to design enzymes for improved activity and specificity and then experimentally validating the computational redesign of the enzymes. Ultimately the methodology will be used to design mutant P450 BM-3 monooxygenase enzymes which are functionally expressed at high levels in E. coli and are used for hydroxylation of small alkanes for alcoholic biofuels. Their target substrates are ethane and propane, with methane the ultimate goal.

The most far-reaching results for this program would be to devise an enzyme that works on methane to produce methanol. Even the development of enzymes capable of rapid and selective oxidation of C1-C3 alkanes could aid in the efficient utilization of remote gas resources or low value refinery gas streams for fuel and chemical generation. The potential is for a new integrated paradigm for enzyme redesign where hypotheses generated by the computational workflow are used to guide the experiment and experimental results serve to correct and complete the computational base.

The educational and outreach efforts will couple the REU approach with attempts to use existing University programs titled SROP, WISER and MURI, all of which are research ?based programs to inspire women and minorities to experience engineering research early in their careers. The PIs plan to include this work in Penn State?s program titled International Genetically Engineered Machines, or IGEM. This program targets high school and undergraduates with hands-on exposure to synthetic biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project 0967062 Outcomes Report

 

The goal of this project was to use computer programs to alter the catalytic properties of enzymes, which are biological catalysts. These catalytic properties include how much substrate is required to reach half of its maximum reaction rate (KM), the speed of the reaction (kcat), and the ratio of these two properties (kcat/KM). One way to alter an enzyme’s behavior is to change the identity of the monomers that constitute the biomolecule. Our group had previously developed a computational tool, called the Iterative Protein Redesign & Optimization (IPRO) procedure, to accomplish this task.

 

We choose a test system of E. coli β-glucuronidase (GUS) for our work. This choice was largely because this enzyme’s structure was known and the product of the catalyzed reaction turns the solution yellow so it was easy to work with experimentally. GUS is capable of catalyzing a reaction using para-nitrophenyl-β,D-glucuronide (pNP-GLU) as the substrate, but not para-nitrophenyl-β,D-galactoside (pNP-GAL). Our work focused on trying to make GUS catalyze the reaction with pNP-GAL but not pNP-GLU (i.e., changing enzyme specificity) by modifying the enzyme with IPRO.

 

Our approach for modeling GUS began by trying to implement a dual modeling approach. We wanted to model the active site (i.e., the part of the enzyme directly affecting catalysis) using accurate quantum mechanics calculations that are based on the electrons’ configuration within the system. However, this level of accuracy cannot be achieved throughout the entire enzyme because there are far too many electrons, and quantum mechanics calculations are computationally expensive. The remainder of the enzyme (i.e., not the active site) used the less accurate molecular modeling, which uses standard equilibrium bond lengths and angles.

 

We sought to formulate a set of correlating expressions that could relate experimentally observable catalytic properties to calculable values. We knew that this formulation must involve the transition state (the highest energy point between reactants and products) since chemical kinetics is dependent upon this energetic barrier. We pursued identification of the transition state structure using quantum mechanics calculations but found that the transition state structure was difficult to resolve. Because of this, we chose to focus on a transition state analogue, which resembles the transition state but is stable so that its structure can be determined. We then formed a set of correlating expressions by evaluating interaction energies (i.e., the energy that holds the ligand and enzyme together) for various complexes.  

 

We found the interaction energy is correlated to KM if the substrate is the ligand, kcat/KM if the transition state analogue is the ligand, and kcat if a combination of the substrate and transition state analogue (although not necessarily weighted equally) are the ligands (see Figure 1). We validated these correlating expressions using mutants (enzymes with changed substituents) with known catalytic properties from literature. Improvement of the interaction energies by generating mutations through IPRO should improve the corresponding catalytic property. This idea formed the basis of the developed computational tool, OptZyme. OptZyme was used to predict improved selectivity for pNP-GAL over pNP-GLU for the GUS system. The results were analyzed to find the critical substitutions affecting selectivity. Furthermore, OptZyme was applied to a new system (i.e., acyl-ACP thioesterase) with applications for biodiesel production.

 


Last ...

These catalytic properties include how much substrate is required to reach half of its maximum reaction rate (KM), the speed of the reaction (kcat), and the ratio of these two properties (kcat/KM). One way to alter an enzymeÆs behavior is to change the identity of the monomers that constitute the biomolecule. Our group had previously developed a computational tool, called the Iterative Protein Redesign & Optimization (IPRO) procedure, to accomplish this task. We choose a test system of E. coli β-glucuronidase (GUS) for our work. This choice was largely because this enzymeÆs structure was known and the product of the catalyzed reaction turns the solution yellow so it was easy to work with experimentally. GUS is capable of catalyzing a reaction using para-nitrophenyl-β,D-glucuronide (pNP-GLU) as the substrate, but not para-nitrophenyl-β,D-galactoside (pNP-GAL). Our work focused on trying to make GUS catalyze the reaction with pNP-GAL but not pNP-GLU (i.e., changing enzyme specificity) by modifying the enzyme with IPRO. Our approach for modeling GUS began by trying to implement a dual modeling approach. We wanted to model the active site (i.e., the part of the enzyme directly affecting catalysis) using accurate quantum mechanics calculations that are based on the electronsÆ configuration within the system. However, this level of accuracy cannot be achieved throughout the entire enzyme because there are far too many electrons, and quantum mechanics calculations are computationally expensive. The remainder of the enzyme (i.e., not the active site) used the less accurate molecular modeling, which uses standard equilibrium bond lengths and angles. We sought to formulate a set of correlating expressions that could relate experimentally observable catalytic properties to calculable values. We knew that this formulation must involve the transition state (the highest energy point between reactants and products) since chemical kinetics is dependent upon this energetic barrier. We pursued identification of the transition state structure using quantum mechanics calculations but found that the transition state structure was difficult to resolve. Because of this, we chose to focus on a transition state analogue, which resembles the transition state but is stable so that its structure can be determined. We then formed a set of correlating expressions by evaluating interaction energies (i.e., the energy that holds the ligand and enzyme together) for various complexes. We found the interaction energy is correlated to KM if the substrate is the ligand, kcat/KM if the transition state analogue is the ligand, and kcat if a combination of the substrate and transition state analogue (although not necessarily weighted equally) are the ligands (see Figure 1).
